results.abstract: Excerpts from conversation with New York University neuroscientist Dr Joseph LeDoux; LeDoux, who has been major force in changing approaches to human brain research, has been finding ways to study how brain processes emotions; he comments on his latest book, The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are; photo (M)

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Joseph LeDoux; Taking a Clinical Look at Human Emotions

keywords.name: creative_works
keywords.value: SYNAPTIC SELF, THE: HOW OUR BRAINS BECOME WHO WE ARE (BOOK)

results.snippet: On a recent balmy evening, Dr. Joseph LeDoux, a professor of neuroscience at New York University, strode to the stage of the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village and read from his latest book, ''The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We...
results.lead_paragraph: On a recent balmy evening, Dr. Joseph LeDoux, a professor of neuroscience at New York University, strode to the stage of the Cornelia Street Cafe in Greenwich Village and read from his latest book, ''The Synaptic Self: How Our Brains Become Who We Are.'' Astonishingly, the audience -- graduate students, publishing executives and scientists --greeted Dr. LeDoux's performance with enthusiasm usually reserved for rock stars.

results.abstract: Pair of astronauts emerger from space shuttle Atlantis to connect and repair plumbing on International Space Station and its latest 14-ton addition; photo of Dr David A Wolf and Dr Piers J Sellers working on space station (M)

headline.main: In 2nd Spacewalk, Astronauts Do the Plumbing

results.snippet: A pair of astronauts emerged from the space shuttle Atlantis today to connect and repair plumbing on the International Space Station and its latest 14-ton addition.    The astronauts, Dr. David A. Wolf and Dr. Piers J. Sellers, hooked up ammonia...
results.lead_paragraph: A pair of astronauts emerged from the space shuttle Atlantis today to connect and repair plumbing on the International Space Station and its latest 14-ton addition. The astronauts, Dr. David A. Wolf and Dr. Piers J. Sellers, hooked up ammonia lines from the recently installed, $390 million girder segment to other cooling pipes. The ammonia will flow throughout the station's chambers, dissipating heat via three external radiators.

results.abstract: Dr Ronald A Malt, Boston surgeon who oversaw first successful reattachment of human limb in 1962, dies at age 70; photo (M)

headline.main: Ronald A. Malt, 70, Is Dead; Innovator in Reattaching Limb

results.snippet: Dr. Ronald A. Malt, a Boston surgeon who made medical history 40 years ago when he oversaw the first successful reattachment of a human limb, died on Oct. 5 in Wellesley, Mass. He was 70.    The cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease, his...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Ronald A. Malt, a Boston surgeon who made medical history 40 years ago when he oversaw the first successful reattachment of a human limb, died on Oct. 5 in Wellesley, Mass. He was 70. The cause was complications from Alzheimer's disease, his family said.

results.abstract: Nancy Better Rituals article discusses shopping on line during heat of summer for children's Halloween costumes; drawing (M)

headline.main: Goodbye, Little Ghost: Halloween Goes Hollywood

results.snippet: I WAS sifting through the mail on a sweltering August day when my 7-year-old son, Charlie, elbowed me aside. He grabbed something with a bright orange cover and waved it triumphantly: the season's first Halloween catalog.    Oh no, I thought. Not...
results.lead_paragraph: I WAS sifting through the mail on a sweltering August day when my 7-year-old son, Charlie, elbowed me aside. He grabbed something with a bright orange cover and waved it triumphantly: the season's first Halloween catalog. Oh no, I thought. Not yet. The annual quest for the perfect costume had begun.

results.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column reports on interviews with women in Saudi Arabia; says women defend dressing in black veils as part of their culture and tradition and are defensive about being stereotyped as repressed; say many emphasize increasing rights being given to women and their determination to solve their problems themselves; concludes that if Saudis choose to kill their economic development and sacrifice international respect by clinging to 15th century, and if women prefer to remain second-class citizens, that is their choice but they should not be surprised that outsiders point and jeer (M)
results.snippet: On my first evening in Riyadh, I spotted a surreal scene: three giggly black ghosts, possibly young women enveloped in black cloaks called abayas, clustered around a display in a shopping mall, enthusiastically fingering a blouse so sheer and low-cut...
results.lead_paragraph: On my first evening in Riyadh, I spotted a surreal scene: three giggly black ghosts, possibly young women enveloped in black cloaks called abayas, clustered around a display in a shopping mall, enthusiastically fingering a blouse so sheer and low-cut that my wife would never be caught dead in it. Afterward, I delicately asked a Saudi woman to explicate the scene. ''What do you think the 'black ghosts' wear underneath their abayas?'' she replied archly.

results.abstract: Article on Joe Finley, third-generation New York City fireman who is Republican candidate for Congress in Long Island's Second Congressional District; Finlay has never run for public office before and is attempting to parlay his September 11 experience into political career; analysts, noting his campaign is hampered by lack of money, predict Democratic incumbent Steve Israel will win race; photo (M)
results.snippet: THIRTEEN months ago Joe Finley of Fort Salonga was just another firefighter commuting between a home in the Long Island suburbs and a firehouse in the city.    These days he is a Republican candidate for Congress, testing whether residents of Long...
results.lead_paragraph: THIRTEEN months ago Joe Finley of Fort Salonga was just another firefighter commuting between a home in the Long Island suburbs and a firehouse in the city. These days he is a Republican candidate for Congress, testing whether residents of Long Island's Second Congressional District will show their esteem at the ballot box for a fireman who rushed to the World Trade Center on Sept. 11 and stayed on to toil in the ruins.
